modules.description: This module implements operations for working with ISO 639-5 language families and groups, including equality checks, lexicographic comparison, and bidirectional conversions to and from ISO 639-5 string codes. It supports data types such as the abstract type `t` representing language families, and provides functions to convert between this type and integers, ISO 639-1 codes, and ISO 639-2 codes (both T and B variants). Concrete use cases include validating ISO 639-5 codes, converting between different ISO 639 standards, and integrating language family data into systems requiring standardized language group identifiers.

This module enables conversion between ISO 639-1, -2, -3, and -5 codes for both individual languages and collective entities such as macrolanguages, language groups, and families, while supporting equality checks, ordering, and classification of these categories. It is designed for applications requiring hierarchical language data handling, such as linguistic databases or internationalization frameworks that need to reconcile granular languages with broader linguistic classifications.

This module provides operations for converting ISO 639-3 language codes to and from ISO 639-1, 639-2T/B variants, and string/integer representations, along with querying language scope (individual/macrolanguage) and hierarchical relationships. It works with abstract language values (`t`), code strings, and numerical identifiers, supporting both safe and partial conversions due to overlapping but distinct coverage across standards. Typical use cases include linguistic data processing, localization systems, and tools requiring interoperability between different ISO 639 code sets for natural languages.

This module handles conversions between ISO 639-1, -2, -3, and -5 language and language family codes, supporting both individual languages and macrolanguages, as well as language groups and families. It works with abstract types representing languages and language families, along with string and integer code representations, enabling precise classification and hierarchical relationships. Concrete use cases include linguistic data validation, internationalization frameworks, and systems requiring interoperability between different ISO 639 code standards.
